elements.content: With solvent molecules participating in coordination systems, four new MnII coordination polymers of the rigid ligand 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC-Cl4) have been obtained from different solvent media. Single-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that the coordination arrays of 1−4 vary from 1D fishbone or zigzag chain for 1 or 2, 2D (4,4) layer for 3, to 3D SrAl2 coordination network for 4, respectively. In {[Mn(BDC-Cl4)(py)2(H2O)2](py)2} n (1) and {[Mn(BDC-Cl4)(MeOH)3](MeOH)} n (2), pyridine/water (in 1) and MeOH (in 2) molecules act as the monodentate terminal ligands to fulfill the metal coordination spheres. In the case of {[Mn(BDC-Cl4)(dioxane)(H2O)2](dioxane)} n (3), the aqua ligand is monodentate and the dioxane moiety displays unusual bridging bidentate mode, whereas for [Mn5(BDC-Cl4)5(DMF)5] n (4), three MnII centers are connected by four BDC-Cl4 ligands and two DMF molecules to constitute a trimeric unit. These secondary units are extended to the final 3D network with SrAl2 (sra) topology. Significantly, the solvents play an essential role in the crystallization and construction of these coordination frameworks with distinct dimensionality and connectivity. The thermal and photoluminescence properties of complexes 1−4 in the solid state have also been discussed.

These secondary units are extended to the final 3D network with SrAl2 (sra) topology. Significantly, the solvents play an essential role in the crystallization and construction of these coordination frameworks with distinct dimensionality and connectivity. The thermal and photoluminescence properties of complexes 1-4 in the solid state have also been discussed.

elements.content: A series of novel metal-organic coordination polymers have been prepared through the assembly of MnII salts with rigid 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid ligand in virtue of different solvent media, the coordination architectures of which display distinct dimensionality and connectivity.
elements.clean_text: A series of novel metal-organic coordination polymers have been prepared through the assembly of MnII salts with rigid 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid ligand in virtue of different solvent media, the coordination architectures of which display distinct dimensionality and connectivity.

elements.content: Self-assemblies of infinite one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D), and three-dimensional (3D) metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) involving transition metal ions and organic ligands have attracted intensive attention in recent years because of their intriguing structural topologies and tailor-made applications as functional solid materials. However, structural modulation of such framework solids is still of an inherent interest and great challenge for their complexity and uncertainty, which may be affected by the selection of bridging ligand, coordination geometry of the metal ion, counteranion, and reaction condition. In this context, the solvent media used in the assembled processes may significantly influence the structures and properties of the resulting coordination frameworks. For instance, Zaworotko et al. have reported the preparation and structural characterization of a series of interesting CoII coordination polymers of supramolecular isomers that are controlled by the crystallizing solvents. Employing different organic bases and solvents, Yaghi et al. have successfully synthesized a series of Zn-BTC (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) frameworks, revealing that their network structures are mainly dependent on the strength of organic base and the solvent media. Schröder and co-workers have presented a series of CdII and ZnII coordination polymers with 3,6-bis(pyridin-3-yl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine obtained from different alcoholic solvents.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Self-assemblies of infinite one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D), and three-dimensional (3D) metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) involving transition metal ions and organic ligands have attracted intensive attention in recent years because of their intriguing structural topologies and tailor-made applications as functional solid materials. However, structural modulation of such framework solids is still of an inherent interest and great challenge for their complexity and uncertainty, which may be affected by the selection of bridging ligand, coordination geometry of the metal ion, counteranion, and reaction condition. In this context, the solvent media used in the assembled processes may significantly influence the structures and properties of the resulting coordination frameworks. For instance, Zaworotko et al. have reported the preparation and structural characterization of a series of interesting CoII coordination polymers of supramolecular isomers that are controlled by the crystallizing solvents. Employing different organic bases and solvents, Yaghi et al. have successfully synthesized a series of Zn-BTC (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) frameworks, revealing that their network structures are mainly dependent on the strength of organic base and the solvent media. Schröder and co-workers have presented a series of CdII and ZnII coordination polymers with 3,6-bis(pyridin-3-yl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine obtained from different alcoholic solvents.

elements.content: Normally, the manner that solvents regulate the crystal structures of coordination complexes can be divided into the following categories: (1) The final crystalline product is free of solvents that however can influence the lattice formation; (2) solvents are incorporated into the structures as guests, that is, not coordinated to the complex moiety; (3) solvents are involved in the coordination solid during crystallization and bound to the metal ions. Under such a condition, most of the solvent components act as terminal ligands and thus will usually decrease the dimensionality of coordination networks, and the fact that the solvents behave as bridging ligands to further expand the metal coordination arrays has quite infrequently been observed.
elements.clean_text: Normally, the manner that solvents regulate the crystal structures of coordination complexes can be divided into the following categories: (1) The final crystalline product is free of solvents that however can influence the lattice formation; (2) solvents are incorporated into the structures as guests, that is, not coordinated to the complex moiety; (3) solvents are involved in the coordination solid during crystallization and bound to the metal ions. Under such a condition, most of the solvent components act as terminal ligands and thus will usually decrease the dimensionality of coordination networks, and the fact that the solvents behave as bridging ligands to further expand the metal coordination arrays has quite infrequently been observed.

elements.content: Recently, the importance of solvent effect on tuning the net structures of MOFs has been further emphasized in the literature. Clearly, the coordination ability and template effect of the solvent molecules can dramatically affect such extended structures, which may afford diverse and aesthetically pleased coordination architectures. However, at this stage, the intrinsic role of solvents on the structural assemblies of MOFs has still not been well-understood. Thus in this work, to further explore this attractive topic, we will present a systematic study of solvent effect in the formation of coordination crystalline products by employing water and common organic solvents, such as pyridine (py), ethanol (EtOH), methanol (MeOH), N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF), and seldom applied 1,4-dioxane (dioxane).

elements.content: On the other hand, the most adequately studied MOFs are based on aromatic di- or polycarboxyl ligands, and the pioneering research of Zaworoko and Yaghi et al. has well-illustrated the utility of this synthetic approach in achieving such crystalline materials with well-defined structures and desired applications. For example, the early reported microporous MOF [Zn(BDC)·(DMF)·(H2O)] is constructed by paddle-wheel secondary building units (SBUs) and ditopic benzene linkers, in which the benzene ring of 1,4-benzenedicaroxylate (BDC) is essentially coplanar with carboxylates to facilitate the formation of a square-based coordination network with available channel space. Because of the steric hindrance effect, the substituents on benzene are expected to result in the rotation of carboxylates out of the benzene plane to give different binding modes upon metal complexation. Much of the recent effort has focused on the design of fascinating coordination architectures with derivatives of BDC by introducing the electron-donating or accepting substituents, such as 2,3,5,6-tetramethyl-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (TBDC) and 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (BDC-F4). However, with the exception of a porous rhodium(II) MOF containing the chlorinated 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate backbone, exploitation of transition metal ions assembling with 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC-Cl4), has not been documented so far. Moreover, it is even rare for solvents modulation of the coordination activity and binding modes of such typical organic spacers and further engineering the dimensionality of final coordination networks, which may hold much promise for further developing the synthesis of coordination polymers.

Moreover, it is even rare for solvents modulation of the coordination activity and binding modes of such typical organic spacers and further engineering the dimensionality of final coordination networks, which may hold much promise for further developing the synthesis of coordination polymers.

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis, structural characterization, and properties of a series of new coordination polymers, including {[Mn(BDC-Cl4)(py)2(H2O)2](py)2} n (1), {[Mn(BDC-Cl4)(MeOH)3](MeOH)} n (2), {[Mn(BDC-Cl4)(dioxane)(H2O)2](dioxane)} n (3), and [Mn5(BDC-Cl4)5(DMF)5] n (4). All these crystalline products were prepared by the reactions of manganese(II) acetate with H2BDC-Cl4 under similar conditions but different solvent media, that is, H2O/pyridine, EtOH/MeOH, H2O/dioxane, and MeOH/DMF for 1−4, respectively (see Scheme ). X-ray diffraction analysis of these network solids reveals the remarkable structural transformation from 1D for 1 and 2, to 2D for 3, and then to 3D for 4.

All these crystalline products were prepared by the reactions of manganese(II) acetate with H2BDC-Cl4 under similar conditions but different solvent media, that is, H2O/pyridine, EtOH/MeOH, H2O/dioxane, and MeOH/DMF for 1-4, respectively (see Scheme ). X-ray diffraction analysis of these network solids reveals the remarkable structural transformation from 1D for 1 and 2, to 2D for 3, and then to 3D for 4.

With the exception of the ligand H2BDC-Cl4, which was prepared according to the literature procedure, all reagents and solvents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet ESP 460 FT-IR spectrometer on KBr pellets in the range of 4000−600 cm−1. Carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen analyses were performed on a PE-2400II (Perkin-Elmer) analyzer. Luminescence spectra of the solid samples were recorded on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out on a Dupont thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C under a N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C /min. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were taken on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer at 60 kV and 300 mA for Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 2°/min and a step size of 0.02° in a 2θ range of 5.00−50.00°.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Materials and Methods

With the exception of the ligand H2BDC-Cl4, which was prepared according to the literature procedure, all reagents and solvents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet ESP 460 FT-IR spectrometer on KBr pellets in the range of 4000-600 cm-1. Carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen analyses were performed on a PE-2400II (Perkin-Elmer) analyzer. Luminescence spectra of the solid samples were recorded on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were carried out on a Dupont thermal analyzer from room temperature to 800 °C under a N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 °C /min. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were taken on a Rigaku D/max-2500 diffractometer at 60 kV and 300 mA for Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 2°/min and a step size of 0.02° in a 2θ range of 5.00-50.00°.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements of 1−4 were performed on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer at the ambient temperature with Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). A semiempirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS, and the program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS program of SHELXTL packages. MnII atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinement was performed by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 with SHELXL program. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon were placed geometrically using a riding mode with the isotropic displacement parameters fixed at 1.2 times U eq of the parent atoms. O-bound H atoms of water or methanol solvents were first located in difference Fourier maps and then fixed in the given positions or refined freely. The methyl groups of methanol and DMF in the structures 2 and 4 are disordered over two sites with equivalent occupancy factors. Further details for structural analysis are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles are listed in .
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction Determination and Refinement

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements of 1-4 were performed on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer at the ambient temperature with Mo Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). A semiempirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS, and the program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS program of SHELXTL packages. MnII atoms in each complex were located from the E-maps, and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinement was performed by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 with SHELXL program. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon were placed geometrically using a riding mode with the isotropic displacement parameters fixed at 1.2 times U eq of the parent atoms. O-bound H atoms of water or methanol solvents were first located in difference Fourier maps and then fixed in the given positions or refined freely. The methyl groups of methanol and DMF in the structures 2 and 4 are disordered over two sites with equivalent occupancy factors. Further details for structural analysis are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles are listed in .

Coordination polymers 1−4 were obtained in different mixed solvent systems by assembling H2BDC-Cl4 with Mn(OAc)2·4H2O in a molar ratio of 1:1 at room temperature. X-ray structural analyses of 1−4 reveal their structural diversity ranging from 1-D (1 and 2), 2-D (3), to 3-D (4) networks, and crystalline species with other structural type such as 0-D or interpenetrating array was not found in such a system. Complexes 1−4 are stable under the ambient conditions and insoluble in common solvents such as water, alcohol, and acetonitrile. The synthetic reproducibility is high. Crystalline phase purity of 1−4 was confirmed by the experimental XRPD patterns, which match well with the corresponding simulated ones obtained from the single-crystal diffraction data (see ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

Coordination polymers 1-4 were obtained in different mixed solvent systems by assembling H2BDC-Cl4 with Mn(OAc)2⋅4H2O in a molar ratio of 1:1 at room temperature. X-ray structural analyses of 1-4 reveal their structural diversity ranging from 1-D (1 and 2), 2-D (3), to 3-D (4) networks, and crystalline species with other structural type such as 0-D or interpenetrating array was not found in such a system. Complexes 1-4 are stable under the ambient conditions and insoluble in common solvents such as water, alcohol, and acetonitrile. The synthetic reproducibility is high. Crystalline phase purity of 1-4 was confirmed by the experimental XRPD patterns, which match well with the corresponding simulated ones obtained from the single-crystal diffraction data (see ).

elements.content: In the IR spectra of 1−4, the absorption bands resulting from the skeletal vibrations of aromatic ring were observed in the 1600−1400 cm−1 region. The absence of band at ∼1720 cm−1 for the free H2BDC-Cl4 molecule in the IR spectra of 1−4 is diagnostic of the complete deprotonation of carboxyl groups. As a result, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate were indicated by strong bands appearing in the range of 1640−1590 cm−1 and 1430−1410 cm−1, respectively. The absorption bands at ∼3400 cm−1 for 1−3 reveal the O−H stretching modes for water or methanol molecules, and their broad feature is attributed to the formation of hydrogen bonding (vide infra).
elements.clean_text: In the IR spectra of 1-4, the absorption bands resulting from the skeletal vibrations of aromatic ring were observed in the 1600-1400 cm-1 region. The absence of band at ~1720 cm-1 for the free H2BDC-Cl4 molecule in the IR spectra of 1-4 is diagnostic of the complete deprotonation of carboxyl groups. As a result, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of carboxylate were indicated by strong bands appearing in the range of 1640-1590 cm-1 and 1430-1410 cm-1, respectively. The absorption bands at ~3400 cm-1 for 1-3 reveal the O-H stretching modes for water or methanol molecules, and their broad feature is attributed to the formation of hydrogen bonding (vide infra).

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal analysis reveals that 1 is a 1D polymeric coordination chain. In the asymmetric unit of 1 (see Figure a), the MnII center adopts a six-coordinated octahedral geometry by coordinating to two oxygen donors (O1 and O1A) from two trans BDC-Cl4 dianions with the Mn−O distance of 2.1637(2) Å, two oxygen atoms from two water molecules with the Mn−O distance of 2.209(2) Å, and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from two trans pyridine molecules with the Mn−N distances of 2.311(3) and 2.330(3) Å. Each BDC−Cl4 dianion bridges two MnII ions in a bis-monodentate fashion to form a 1-D linear chain (Figure b). Within the linear chain, the distance between successive MnII ions is 11.570 Å, and the closest Mn···Mn separation between the neighboring strands is 9.403 Å.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Mn(BDC-Cl4)(py)2(H2O)2](py)2} n  (1)

X-ray single-crystal analysis reveals that 1 is a 1D polymeric coordination chain. In the asymmetric unit of 1 (see Figure a), the MnII center adopts a six-coordinated octahedral geometry by coordinating to two oxygen donors (O1 and O1A) from two trans BDC-Cl4 dianions with the Mn-O distance of 2.1637(2) Å, two oxygen atoms from two water molecules with the Mn-O distance of 2.209(2) Å, and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from two trans pyridine molecules with the Mn-N distances of 2.311(3) and 2.330(3) Å. Each BDC-Cl4 dianion bridges two MnII ions in a bis-monodentate fashion to form a 1-D linear chain (Figure b). Within the linear chain, the distance between successive MnII ions is 11.570 Å, and the closest Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn separation between the neighboring strands is 9.403 Å.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that because of the steric hindrance of the chlorine atoms located at the ortho positions of carboxylate, the rotation angle (φrot) of tetrachlorinated phenyl ring relative to carboxylate is 88.2°, which is similar to those of other carboxylate compounds with polychlorinated backbone. In a similar way to the structure of {[Co(bpdc)(py)2(H2O)2]·2py} n (bpdc = 4,4′-biphenyldicaroxylate), each coordinated water molecule is involved in the strong intramolecular hydrogen bond (O3−H3A···O2i, H···O/O···O distances: 1.94/2.750(3) Å, angle: 158°, i = −x + 2, y, −z + 1/2) to the uncoordinated carboxylate O2 atom of BDC-Cl4. Notably, each aqua ligand also forms a strong intermolecular hydrogen bond (O3−H3B···N3ii, H···N/O···N distances: 1.93/2.783(4) Å, angle: 177°, ii = x + 1, y, z) with the included pyridine moiety (Figure a). Between the adjacent chains, the occurrence of weak edge-to-face C−H···π [C6−H6···Cg1iii (Cg1 = N1, C8−C10, C8A, C9A): H6···Cg1, 2.94 Å, C6···Cg1, 3.697(4) Å, iii = x − 1/2, y − 1/2, z] intermolecular interactions results in a 3-D supramolecular network (Figure c). Further investigation of the crystal packing indicates that the pyridine guests are engaged in the face-to-face π−π interactions with the center-to-center distances of 3.478(3) and 3.585(3) Å. Thus, alternatively, we could consider that these parallel 1D coordination chains are further extended to a 2D supramolecular motif by means of aromatic stacking (see the ).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 2 contains one-dimensional zigzag coordination polymer chains with dinuclear subunits. As shown in Figure a, each Mn center is six-coordinated and surrounded by one mirror-symmetric bidentate BDC-Cl4 ligand and two centrosymmetric BDC-Cl4 spacers in bis-bidentate coordination mode, as well as three terminal methanol ligands. The Mn−O bond distances vary from 2.112(3) to 2.240(3) Å and the O−Mn−O bond angles range from 81.91(9) to 171.01(9)°. The secondary building unit (SBU) containing a centrosymmetric binuclear core is formed, in which two Mn ions with Mn···Mn distance of 4.230 Å are bridged by μ-carboxylate groups of three pairs of ligated BDC-Cl4. Within each BDC-Cl4 ligand, the value of φrot between tetrachlorinated phenyl ring and carboxylate is 90.0°. Such binuclear units are further expanded to form a zigzag chain by the linkage of bis-bidentate BDC-Cl4 (Figure b). Meanwhile, these adjacent 1D arrays are connected through O4−H4B···O3i hydrogen bonds (H···O/O···O distance: 1.98/2.725(3) Å, angle: 147(3)°; i = x + 1/2, y − 1/2, z) between the methanol ligands and uncoordinated carboxylate O3 atoms of BDC-Cl4, leading to the formation of a 3D supramolecular architecture, as illustrated in Figure c.

elements.content: In this structure, each Mn ion is octahedrally coordinated (MnO6) to two bis-monodentate BDC-Cl4 ligands (O3 and O3A), two terminal aqua molecules (O4 and O4A), and two bridging dioxane (O5 and O5A) (Figure a). In each BDC-Cl4 ligand, tetrachlorinated phenyl ring inclines to carboxylate with a φrot value of 81.9°. The bond distances of Mn1−O3 and Mn1−O5 are 2.103(1) and 2.354(2) Å, respectively. The O4 and O4A atoms occupy the axial sites with the Mn1−O4 distance of 2.178(2) Å (between those of Mn1−O3 and Mn1−O5). As depicted in Figure a, the Mn atoms coordinate to two trans-BDC-Cl4 and two chair dioxane ligands, and both kinds of organic components adopt the bridging forms. As a result, a (4,4) 2D net with approximately rectangular grids of 11.449 Å × 7.547 Å (Mn···Mn nucleus-to-nucleus) is generated, in which the Mn···Mn···Mn angles are 91.0 and 89.0°, respectively.

Crystal Structure of {[Mn(BDC-Cl4)(dioxane)(H2O)2](dioxane)} n  (3)

In this structure, each Mn ion is octahedrally coordinated (MnO6) to two bis-monodentate BDC-Cl4 ligands (O3 and O3A), two terminal aqua molecules (O4 and O4A), and two bridging dioxane (O5 and O5A) (Figure a). In each BDC-Cl4 ligand, tetrachlorinated phenyl ring inclines to carboxylate with a φrot value of 81.9°. The bond distances of Mn1-O3 and Mn1-O5 are 2.103(1) and 2.354(2) Å, respectively. The O4 and O4A atoms occupy the axial sites with the Mn1-O4 distance of 2.178(2) Å (between those of Mn1-O3 and Mn1-O5). As depicted in Figure a, the Mn atoms coordinate to two trans-BDC-Cl4 and two chair dioxane ligands, and both kinds of organic components adopt the bridging forms. As a result, a (4,4) 2D net with approximately rectangular grids of 11.449 Å × 7.547 Å (Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn nucleus-to-nucleus) is generated, in which the Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn angles are 91.0 and 89.0°, respectively.

elements.content: The dioxane molecule usually participates in coordinating with metal ions in the bridging or terminal fashion. A number of coordination polymers have been reported in which 1,4-dioxane bridges the transition metal ions (such as Zn, Ni, Co, Cu, Hg, and Cd) to provide supramolecular architectures with variform topological motifs. Although 1,4-dioxane is found to act as the terminal ligand in a previously reported chiral (salen) MnIII complex [Mn(salen)(dioxane)(H2O)]·(ClO4)·(dioxane)·(benzene) (salen = (R,R)-N,N′-bis(3,5-di-tert-butyl-salicylidene)-1,2-cyclohexanediamine), Complex 3 is a rare example of MnII coordination polymer in which the dioxane molecule coordinates to MnII as bridge and finally plays a key role in controlling the resulting polymeric network.

A number of coordination polymers have been reported in which 1,4-dioxane bridges the transition metal ions (such as Zn, Ni, Co, Cu, Hg, and Cd) to provide supramolecular architectures with variform topological motifs. Although 1,4-dioxane is found to act as the terminal ligand in a previously reported chiral (salen) MnIII complex [Mn(salen)(dioxane)(H2O)]⋅(ClO4)⋅(dioxane)⋅(benzene) (salen = (R,R)-N,N'-bis(3,5-di-tert-butyl-salicylidene)-1,2-cyclohexanediamine), Complex 3 is a rare example of MnII coordination polymer in which the dioxane molecule coordinates to MnII as bridge and finally plays a key role in controlling the resulting polymeric network.

elements.content: Further, there exist diverse hydrogen-bonding motifs in the crystal lattice of 3. Each H4A atom of the coordinated water is hydrogen bonded to two separate oxygen atoms (O2A from adjacent polymeric layers, O4···O2/O2A 2.817/2.955 Å, angles: 147/127°, Figure a), to form a 4-membered ring. Through such H-bonding, the coordination layers are extended to build up a 3D network with 1D channels (cross section with the dimension of ca. 6.6 Å × 5.2 Å, nucleus-to-nucleus), as shown in Figure b. The channels possess the volume of 109.2 Å3, corresponding to 19.9% of the unit cell volume of 3 as evaluated by PLATON, which are occupied by the free chair-form dioxane molecules. In consideration of the O4−H4B···O1 hydrogen bonds (O4···O1, 2.880 Å, angle: 166°), the guest dioxane may serve as supramolecular templates and are beneficial to the stability of this 3D system.

elements.content: X-ray structural analysis shows that complex 4 has a 3D coordination framework crystallizing in Imma space group. The fundamental building unit of 4 is composed of two and a half MnII centers, BDC-Cl4, and DMF ligands. Within three distinct BDC-Cl4 ligands, the values of φrot between tetrachlorinated phenyl ring and carboxylate are 89.0, 88.9, and 90.0°, respectively. Three crystallographically independent MnII ions have similar octahedral coordination geometry provided by six oxygen atoms from two pairs of mirror-symmetric anionic BDC-Cl4 ligands and two axially DMF molecules. The Mn−O bond distances are in the range of 2.065(2) −2.267(3) Å. Each BDC-Cl4 ligand is bound to four MnII ions in the bridging bis-bidentate fashion. Notably, μ2-O atoms of DMF, associating with a pair of carboxylates, bridge the metal centers into a 1D infinite chain along [010]. Each anionic BDC-Cl4 separates the metal ions by the distance of ca. 10.9 Å. If we regard each trinuclear Mn center as a 4-connected SBU (Figure a), the resultant 3D coordination network could be described as a uninodal 4-c net of rare sra topology with Schläfli symbol of (42.63.8), as depicted in Figure b, which is related to the structural prototype of zeolite ABW (or SrAl2).

Crystal Structure of [Mn5(BDC-Cl4)5(DMF)5] n  (4)

X-ray structural analysis shows that complex 4 has a 3D coordination framework crystallizing in Imma space group. The fundamental building unit of 4 is composed of two and a half MnII centers, BDC-Cl4, and DMF ligands. Within three distinct BDC-Cl4 ligands, the values of φrot between tetrachlorinated phenyl ring and carboxylate are 89.0, 88.9, and 90.0°, respectively. Three crystallographically independent MnII ions have similar octahedral coordination geometry provided by six oxygen atoms from two pairs of mirror-symmetric anionic BDC-Cl4 ligands and two axially DMF molecules. The Mn-O bond distances are in the range of 2.065(2) -2.267(3) Å. Each BDC-Cl4 ligand is bound to four MnII ions in the bridging bis-bidentate fashion. Notably, μ2-O atoms of DMF, associating with a pair of carboxylates, bridge the metal centers into a 1D infinite chain along [010]. Each anionic BDC-Cl4 separates the metal ions by the distance of ca. 10.9 Å. If we regard each trinuclear Mn center as a 4-connected SBU (Figure a), the resultant 3D coordination network could be described as a uninodal 4-c net of rare sra topology with Schläfli symbol of (42.63.8), as depicted in Figure b, which is related to the structural prototype of zeolite ABW (or SrAl2).

elements.content: Alternatively, if the metal ions and BDC-Cl4 ligands are individually considered as network nodes, each Mn atom acts as a 6-connected node to join four neighboring 4-connected BDC-Cl4 nodes and two adjacent MnII centers are also linked through the carbonyl of DMF. Thus, the ligands and metals are interconnected to generate a 3-D (4,6)-connected network (Figure c) with the Schläfli symbol of (32.62.72)(34.42.64.75), which is unprecedented. In addition, due to the existence of obstructive chlorine and terminal DMF entities, such a 3D framework has very small voids of 63.8 Å3 (only 0.8% of the unit cell volume) as calculated by PLATON, and thus no guest molecules are included.

Thus, the ligands and metals are interconnected to generate a 3-D (4,6)-connected network (Figure c) with the Schläfli symbol of (32.62.72)(34.42.64.75), which is unprecedented. In addition, due to the existence of obstructive chlorine and terminal DMF entities, such a 3D framework has very small voids of 63.8 Å3 (only 0.8% of the unit cell volume) as calculated by PLATON, and thus no guest molecules are included.

elements.content: From above results, the role of solvent in determining the network structures of such Mn-dicarboxylate coordination polymers has been clearly exhibited. As a matter of fact, the coordination frameworks of 1−4 can be strongly affected by the binding ability of the solvent ligand such as its coordination competition and/or mode. A comparison of such solvent-controlled Mn-BDC-Cl4 net systems of complexes 1−4 is summarized in Table . It is immediately apparent that ethanol and methanol molecules are not incorporated into the final crystal lattices of complexes 2 and 4, respectively, and only serve as the reaction media, being essentially consistent with the coordination ability in the order of DMF > MeOH > EtOH. It is known that solvents acting as terminal ligands will normally destroy the connectivity and dimensionality of the resulting coordination frameworks, while some other solvents may also play a role to extend the polymeric networks as available bridging ligands. In this work, pyridine/water (or MeOH) molecules in 1 (or 2) act as terminal monodentate ligands, affording 1-D chain coordination arrays, whereas in complex 3, the monodentate aqua ligand and bridging dioxane moiety in unusual bidentate mode facilitate the formation of 2D coordination layer. In the case of 4, no terminal solvent ligand was found in such a polymeric structure, and only DMF molecules in bridging binding form are incorporated in the final 3D coordination network. As stated above, terminal solvent ligands hold back the introducing of more bridging building blocks in the reliable octahedral coordination sphere of MnII center and then reduce the dimensionality of resultant metal-organic frameworks. As far as we know, BDC has been extensively used as effective linker in the construction of supramolecular architectures owing to its diverse coordination modes and bridging ability. As an analogue of BDC, the BDC-Cl4 ligand displays two coordination modes in the complexes presented here, namely bis-monodentate (in 1 and 3, Scheme a), and bridging bis-bidentate (in 2 and 4, Scheme b), respectively, which may be subtly modulated via the choice of solvent system. The values of φrot within the BDC-Cl4 backbone vary from 81.9 to 90.0°, and it seems that the low φrot is responsible for the formation of monodentate mode of carboxylate. Notably, the similar coordination fashions of the BDC-Cl4 ligands afford a binuclear SBU in 2 (Scheme c) and a trinuclear SBU in 4 (Scheme d), which result in significant discrepancy in the final coordination networks.

As a matter of fact, the coordination frameworks of 1-4 can be strongly affected by the binding ability of the solvent ligand such as its coordination competition and/or mode. Thermal stability of coordination polymers 1−4 has been investigated by TG−DSC technique and the thermogravimetric curves are shown in . The TG analysis shows that weight loss of 1 begins at 45 °C, and the lattice pyridine moiety is lost from 45 to 95 °C (calcd, 22.3%; found, 23.4%) with endothermic peaking at 83 °C. The remaining framework is decomposed through three consecutive weight losses beginning at 95 °C and not ending at 800 °C. The TGA trace of 2 reveals that the first weight loss occurs in the temperature range of 30−115 °C, which can be attributed to the complete removal of methanol guests (calcd, 9.5%; found, 9.8%). A sharp weight loss occurs with an onset temperature for degradation of ca. 230 °C (endothermic peak: 359 °C), followed by a slow weight loss not ending until 800 °C. In the case of 3, the weight loss of 6.7% occurring from room temperature to 260 °C corresponds to the release of partial dioxane solvents. Then a sharp weight loss happens in the temperature range of 260−400 °C with endothermic peaking at 346 °C, indicating collapse of the residual framework. Two consecutive weight losses are then found and do not end until heating to 800 °C. Complex 4 shows high thermal stability with the mass remaining largely unchanged until the decomposition onset temperature of ca. 295 °C. Critical weight losses in the temperature range of 295−450 °C indicate the pyrolysis of organic components with the endothermic peak value of 353 °C.

elements.content: The emission spectra of complexes 1−4, and the organic ligand H2BDC-Cl4, under excitation of 340 nm in the solid state at room temperature are shown in Figure . The strongest emission peak for free ligand appears at 474 nm, corresponding to the n → π* transitions. For 1−4, the maximum emission peaks are similarly observed at 481 nm, which are tentatively attributed to the intraligand transitions. The small red-shift (Δλ = 7 nm) in comparison to that of the free ligand may be attributed to effect of metal coordination. In addition, the weaker shoulder peaks of the emission spectra at 511 nm can probably be assigned to the intraligand transition because a similar peak at about 512 nm also appears for the ligand H2BDC-Cl4. Furthermore, the emission intensity of complexes 1−4 are significantly weaker than that of the free ligand, which is likely related to their complicated structures as well as the decay effect of high-energy C−H and/or O−H oscillatrors from lattice and coordinated solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The emission spectra of complexes 1-4, and the organic ligand H2BDC-Cl4, under excitation of 340 nm in the solid state at room temperature are shown in Figure . The strongest emission peak for free ligand appears at 474 nm, corresponding to the n → π* transitions. For 1-4, the maximum emission peaks are similarly observed at 481 nm, which are tentatively attributed to the intraligand transitions. The small red-shift (Δλ = 7 nm) in comparison to that of the free ligand may be attributed to effect of metal coordination. In addition, the weaker shoulder peaks of the emission spectra at 511 nm can probably be assigned to the intraligand transition because a similar peak at about 512 nm also appears for the ligand H2BDC-Cl4. Furthermore, the emission intensity of complexes 1-4 are significantly weaker than that of the free ligand, which is likely related to their complicated structures as well as the decay effect of high-energy C-H and/or O-H oscillatrors from lattice and coordinated solvent molecules.

elements.content: A series of MnII coordination polymers with the chlorinated benzenedicarboxylate bridging ligand BDC-Cl4 have been synthesized and structurally characterized, and the present work provides a systemic exploration on the construction of diverse polymeric networks by only changing the solvent media. The resultant coordination frameworks, varying from 1D (1 and 2), 2D (3) to 3D (4), are profoundly influenced by the solvents that are normally act as ancillary coligands with different binding modes. Further study on the crystal packing of 1−3 indicates that the secondary interactions such as hydrogen bonding and aromatic stacking are also critical to fulfill the final 3D supramolecular lattices. The network structure of 4 reveals a 3D coordination framework with unprecedented (4,6)-connectivity or sra topology. Anyway, this work evidently demonstrates that the nature of solvents is responsible for the structural diversification of MnII-carboxylate systems, which may offer new information on the further design and crystal engineering of such polymeric crystalline materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion and Comments

A series of MnII coordination polymers with the chlorinated benzenedicarboxylate bridging ligand BDC-Cl4 have been synthesized and structurally characterized, and the present work provides a systemic exploration on the construction of diverse polymeric networks by only changing the solvent media. The resultant coordination frameworks, varying from 1D (1 and 2), 2D (3) to 3D (4), are profoundly influenced by the solvents that are normally act as ancillary coligands with different binding modes. Further study on the crystal packing of 1-3 indicates that the secondary interactions such as hydrogen bonding and aromatic stacking are also critical to fulfill the final 3D supramolecular lattices. The network structure of 4 reveals a 3D coordination framework with unprecedented (4,6)-connectivity or sra topology. Anyway, this work evidently demonstrates that the nature of solvents is responsible for the structural diversification of MnII-carboxylate systems, which may offer new information on the further design and crystal engineering of such polymeric crystalline materials.

Complex 1 was prepared by the mixing of equal molar H2BDC-Cl4 (30.4 mg, 0.10 mmol) and Mn(OAc)2·4H2O (24.5 mg, 0.10 mmol) in a pyridine/water medium. After ca. 30 min of being stirred, the colorless solution was filtered and left to stand at room temperature. Block colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvents in ca. 75% yield (53.2 mg, on the basis of H2BDC-Cl4). Elemental anal. (%) Calcd for C28H24Cl4MnN4O6: C, 47.42; H, 3.41; N, 7.90. Found: C, 47.35; H, 3.42; N, 7.93. cln_elements.content:
Further, there exist diverse hydrogen-bonding motifs in the crystal lattice of 3. Each H4A atom of the coordinated water is hydrogen bonded to two separate oxygen atoms (O2A from adjacent polymeric layers, O4···O2/O2A 2.817/2.955 Å, angles: 147/127°, Figure a), to form a 4-membered ring. Through such H-bonding, the coordination layers are extended to build up a 3D network with 1D channels (cross section with the dimension of ca. 6.6 Å × 5.2 Å, nucleus-to-nucleus), as shown in Figure b. The channels possess the volume of 109.2 Å3, corresponding to 19.9% of the unit cell volume of 3 as evaluated by PLATON, which are occupied by the free chair-form dioxane molecules. In consideration of the O4−H4B···O1 hydrogen bonds (O4···O1, 2.880 Å, angle: 166°), the guest dioxane may serve as supramolecular templates and are beneficial to the stability of this 3D system.

Thermal Stability

Thermal stability of coordination polymers 1−4 has been investigated by TG−DSC technique and the thermogravimetric curves are shown in . The TG analysis shows that weight loss of 1 begins at 45 °C, and the lattice pyridine moiety is lost from 45 to 95 °C (calcd, 22.3%; found, 23.4%) with endothermic peaking at 83 °C. The remaining framework is decomposed through three consecutive weight losses beginning at 95 °C and not ending at 800 °C. The TGA trace of 2 reveals that the first weight loss occurs in the temperature range of 30−115 °C, which can be attributed to the complete removal of methanol guests (calcd, 9.5%; found, 9.8%). A sharp weight loss occurs with an onset temperature for degradation of ca. 230 °C (endothermic peak: 359 °C), followed by a slow weight loss not ending until 800 °C. In the case of 3, the weight loss of 6.7% occurring from room temperature to 260 °C corresponds to the release of partial dioxane solvents. Then a sharp weight loss happens in the temperature range of 260−400 °C with endothermic peaking at 346 °C, indicating collapse of the residual framework. Two consecutive weight losses are then found and do not end until heating to 800 °C. Complex 4 shows high thermal stability with the mass remaining largely unchanged until the decomposition onset temperature of ca. 295 °C. Critical weight losses in the temperature range of 295−450 °C indicate the pyrolysis of organic components with the endothermic peak value of 353 °C.
